step.description: Check if the small PCB - SFP extension plug (E-3), fits in the SFP module sleeve. Also check the SFP module sleeve fits in the media converter. In the case it does not, check printer settings and reprint the part.
Re-drill four holes with 11mm drill or reamer. Check that the metal rod slides trough each hole easily.
Re-drill two front small holes with 3mm drill. Do not re-drill other eight holes!
Re-drill two holes with 8.1mm drill or reamer.
Re-drill the middle hole with 4mm drill.
Re-drill all nine holes with 3mm drill.
Re-drill nine holes on the top with 3mm drill.
Drill four side holes with 4mm drill.
Re-drill nine holes with 3mm drill. Re-drill four holes with 8.1mm drill, be careful not to drill them trough the part.
Re-drill nine holes with 3mm drill. User a drill or a reamer for the 12mm hole. Re-drill four holes with 8.1mm drill.
Re-drill nine holes on the bottom, two on the sides and two on the top with 3mm drill.
Re-drill four holes with 8.1mm drill or reamer.
Check that the metal rod slides trough each hole easily.
Re-drill a hole in both parts with 3mm drill.
Re-drill a hole in both parts with 3mm drill.
Re-drill two holes with 8.1mm drill or reamer.
Check that the metal rod slides trough both holes easily.
Re-drill 4 holes with 8.1mm drill or reamer.
Check that the metal rod slides trough each hole easily.
Re-drill two holes with 3mm drill.
Re-drill both holes in each bracket with 3mm drill.
If the part is 3D printed, re-drill eight holes with 3mm drill.
Grind rough edges of the rod.

physical_part.description: Set screw HEX socket DIN913 M3x16

step.description: Re-drill the hole with 3mm drill.

physical_part.description: Screw round head square neck bolt DIN603 M10x75

brick.name: KORUZA
brick.abstract: 1Gbps networking connectivity for locations up to 100m apart, using an eye-safe infrared light beam.
brick.long_description: KORUZA is a low cost, open source and open hardware, wireless optical system, making the free space optical (FSO) technology available to masses and providing an alternative to Wi-Fi networks.

step.description: Begin by manufacturing all 3D printed parts. Follow the instructions in the Manufacturing section. If using KORUZA DIY kit, 3D printed parts are already included.
Some parts need additional treatment. Detailed instructions are enclosed to each part. If using KORUZA DIY kit with included 3D printed parts, they do not need any additional treatment.
Assemble the electronics by flowing instructions in the Electronics section.
Finally, follow the instructions in the Mechanical section. Assemble all mechanical modules. Instructions on how to combine mechanical and electronics modules can be found there as well.

brick.name: Manufacturing
brick.abstract: Manufacturing and additional treatment of 3D printed and other custom made parts.
brick.long_description: Most of the costume made parts used in the KORUZA system are 3D printed, using affordable 3D printers. While those parts are already included in the DIY kit, one can print them out on its own as well. Note that most of the parts need additional treatment to achieve optimal fit and precision. DIY kit parts need additional treatment as well!

step.description:
1. The assembly procedure of KORUZA units requires the following tools: - inbus M3, - inbus M4, - M3 TORX screwdriver, - small electrical flat screwdriver, - power drill, - 3mm drill, - 4mm drill, - 8.1mm drill, - 11mm reamer (alternatively drill), - calliper, - utility knife, - socket wrench 17 - socket wrench 13.
The following tools may come handy, but are not necessary: - rubber hammer, - drill press.
First print all 3D printed parts. If you are using KORUZA DIY kits they are already included.

For each 3D printed part you can find enclosed stl file and appropriate printer settings, tested on open-source TrubleMaker printer. Shell thickness, bottom/top thickness and fill density settings are applicable for other 3D printers as well, while other may wary depending on the printer used. By default shell and bottom/top thickness are set to 2mm and fill density to 20% for all parts.
Some parts need additional treatment. Follow the instructions carefully to achieve optimal fit for later assembly. Parts included in DIY kit do not need any additional treatment.
When re-drilling holes we recommend using the drill press. Pay close attention to always drill perpendicular to the part surface.

brick.name: Electronics
brick.abstract: Electronical components of the KORUZA system.
brick.long_description: Several electronic components implement the main functions of the system and monitor its performance. The electronics consist of five micro-controllers and a RaspberyPi unit. They control movements of the unit carried out by three motors, used to achieved optimal alignment, monitor power supply, performance of the SFP and media converter.

step.description: We will first assemble the control electronics. You need to prepare the power module PCB (E-1), Raspberry pi shield (E-2) and the Raspberry Pi 2B microcomputer (E-6).
Take the power module PCB (E-1), two M3 male-female spacers (M-O9) and two M3 nuts (M-F11).
Insert spacers trough side holes on the PCB and fasten them with nuts. Keep in mind male side must be pointing up.
Take the Raspberry Pi PCB shield (E-2). Prepare two more spacers (M-O9), two M3 nuts (M-F11) and two M3 washers (M-F14).
Put washer on two spacers and attach them to the side of the shield PCB with connectors. Fasten them with the nuts.
Insert the power cable (E-18) into the screw terminal (the one located in the middle of the side with connectors), mind the polarity.
Attach the micromatch cable (E-17) on the connector, next to the power cable.
Attach the two PCB boards, such that the power module is located on top of the Raspberry Pi shield, as shown in the photo.
Take two spacers (M-O9).
Attach spacers on the bottom side of the Raspberry Pi shield, so that they connect with the spacers already attached on the Power module PCB.
Take the Raspberry Pi PCB.
Put the assembled PCB shield on top of the Raspberry Pi as shown on the photo.
Take four more spacers (M-O9).
Attach them to the Raspberry Pi PCB.
To assemble the SFP plug prepare the SFP extension plug PCB (E-3), 3D printed SFP module sleeve (M-P1), short IDC cable (E-15) and SATA cable (E-16).
Insert the SFP plug into the 3D printed sleeve, such that the connectors are pointing to the back side of the sleeve.
Attach IDC and SATA cables to the provided connectors.

brick.name: Mechanical
brick.abstract: Mechanical modules of the KORUZA system.
brick.long_description: Mechanical part of the system provides the enclosure and frame for mounting electronic components, as well as allowing later adjustments in pointing direction, focus and laser alignment. Fully modular design, connected with stainless steel rods, allows for straightforward adjustments and modifications of any module, without affecting the whole design.

step.description: Begin by assembling the mounting sub-module.
Continue with the SFP Mount sub-module.
Modify the media converter...
...and assemble the media converter mount.
Take the assembled SFP extension plug. Attach SATA cable to SFP extension socket board and plug the IDC cable to the left slot on the PCB board.
Take the long IDC cable (E-14) and plug it into the right slot on the SFP extension socket board.
Assemble the motor mount sub-module.
Prepare four steel rods (M-O2) and assembled sub-modules.
Take the mounting sub-module part. Put rods into the holes. If rods do not fit, re-drill holes with the 8.1mm drill. Hammer them all the way in.
Tighten two M4 set screws on the laser mount.
Take the assembled SFP mount part.
Insert the whole assembly on rails. Take the long IDC cable (E-14) and plug it into the right slot on the SFP extension socket board.
Slide the assembly down, such that the distance between inner edge of the rubber and outer edge of SFP module is 68mm.
Take the assembled media converter mount.
Insert the part on the rails such that it sits just below the SATA connector. Optional: you may disconnect the SATA cable during the procedure.
Take the assembled motor mount.
Insert it on the rods. Tighten the set screws.

Connect motors to the PCB on top. Connect the z-motor (located next to the SFP module) to the first connector, the y-motor (facing the media converter) to the second and x-motor to the last connector.
Prepare the Philips media converter. Take the power supply cable with the connector (E-19) and plug it in the power socket.
Place the media converter next to the rails. Turn it so that the UTP and SFP ports are pointing upwards and and TP-link title towards the KORUZA assembly. Plug in the PCB socket.
Use four TORX M3x10 screws, already inserted in holes, to attach brackets to the laser mount and media converter mount.
Thread the wires of the power supply cable and laser behind the brackets on the right side of media converter to the top.
Tighten set screws on the motor mount.
Take the 3D printed half-bracet and attach it to the motor mount with the TORX M3 screw, already inserted in the part. Thread the wires behind it.
Insert the power cable (E-18) into the screw terminal (closest to the corner of the board) on the top PCB, mind the polarity.
Connect the laser wires in the slot labelled 'laser' on the top PCB board.
Take the assembled lid.
Connect the power cable from the lid to the second screw terminal on the top PCB, mind the polarity.
Connect the long IDC cable, attached to the SFP extension socket board, to the PCB on the lid. Connector is located next to the power cable.
Connect the the micromatch cable, attached to the lid, to the top PCB board. Connector is located next to the screw terminals.
Insert UTP plug into the media converter.

brick.name: Mounting
brick.abstract: Mounting module, holding KORUZA system fixed in the enclosure.
brick.long_description: Mounting module provides a stable frame for optical components of the system: lens and green laser, used for initial visual alignment. It is also responsible for holding KORUZA system fixed in the outer enclosure. Consisting of mostly 3D printed parts, a rubber layer is added to enable fine movements in the calibration process and acts as a seal.

step.description: Take the 3D printed inner ring (M-P5).
Insert four M4 square nuts (M-F12) into the provided slots.
Help yourself with pliers to insert the nuts.
Push nuts all the way in with the screwdriver.
Insert four HEX socket M4x12 screws (M-F7) with M4 washers (M-F15) on them . Do not tighten them fully.
Take the 3D printed outer ring (M-P4) and nine HEX socket M3x35 screws (M-F4). The outer ring needs to be positioned in such a way, that smooth side is pointing upwords.
Insert M3 screws trough the provided holes, such that screw heads are located on the smooth surface.
Prepare the custum made rubber (M-O1).
Put the rubber on the screws. Keep in mind that holes are not symmetrical to preserve the correct orientation.
Prepare the innerr ring (M-P5).
Place the inner ring on top of the assembled structure. Keep in mind the orientation, such that screws are nicely aligned.
Tighten M3 screws with M3 nuts (M-F11), such that they firmly hold the rubber, but do not tighten them fully.
Take the laser mount part (M-P8) and 13 M3 square nuts (M-F11).
Insert M3 square nuts into the laser mount part. Use pliers.
Insert two M4 nuts (M-F12).
Insert the two HEX socket M4x12 screws (M-F7) into the holes but do not tighten them.
Insert two TORX M3x10 screws (M-F6) into the side holes, do not tighten them fully.
Prepare the lens outer ring (M-P6) and insert nine HEX socket M3x35 screws (M-F4) trough the lens outer ring, from the side which does not have 8mm holes.
Take the outer part...
... and place the outer ring trough the rubber,...
...such that the screws are on the same side as ones on the outer ring.
Take the lens mount part (M-P7) and clean the edge if needed.
Insert the lens (M-O3) with the curve part pointing outwards.
Insert the lens mounting ring on the screws from the inside, ...
...such that the retaining edge is pointing to the rubber.
Insert the laser pointer (E-9) such that it sits nicely in the rubber.
Tread the wires of the laser trough the hole in the laser mount.
Screw the laser mount part trough the inner ring.
Take two wedges (M-P9 and M-P10). Fit the two M3 square nuts (M-F11) inside the provided slots. Optional: use pliers.
They need to fit the whole way in.
Insert both wedges into the laser mount.
Take the two HEX socket M3x25 screws (M-F3) and fit them trough the wedge.
Tighten them.
Fit the M3 square nut (M-F11) inside the provided slot. ake the spring (M-O4) and fit it between the aiming laser and the provided hole with the nut inside.
Insert the set screw HEX socket M3x16 (M-F1) trough the hole, nut and spring. Do not screw it the whole way trough!

brick.name: SFP Mount
brick.abstract: Mechanical module, used for mounting the SFP and media converter.
brick.long_description: SFP mounting module provides stable foundation for mounting the SFP and media converter. Based around 3D printed SFP mount part, fastened on the metal rods, part is easily moved at optimal distance from the lens. Small motor, also contained in the module, is used for collimation process, adjusting distance between the lens and SFP module.

step.description: Prepare 3D printed SFP mount (M-P2) and SFP spring mount (M-P3), together with the inner SFP mounting part (M-P14) and SFP module (E-8).
Take the SFP mount part (M-P2).
Push 4 sliding bushings (M-O6) in holes from the bottom...
... and two from the top. Check that the peace easily slides on the rods. If it does not slide nicely, take bushings out and ream holes again.
Insert two M3 square nuts (M-F11) in provided slots on the SFP mount part.
Take the custom SFP mount part (M-P14). Put eight HEX socket M3x25 screws (M-F3) trough holes and screw it to the SFP mount.
Add M3 nuts (M-F11).
Insert the set screw - HEX socket M3x16 (M-F1) into the aluminium part and screw it with the hex key until it comes to the inside.
Insert the SFP module (E-8) into the part, so that the back edge of the SFP module is flat with the aluminium part. Tighten the SFP set screw.
Insert the KORUZA SFP extension socket PCB (E-4) on the SFP module.
Insert the TORX M3x10 screw (M-F6) to hold the board in place. Place a M3 washer (M-F14) between board and SFP mount. Fast the screw with the M3 square nut (M-F11).
Fit the HEX M4x35 screw (M-F9) with the coupler M4 (M-P11) to the motor (E-10) and put the washer (M-F15) on the screw.
Insert the whole thing onto the mounting part.
Mount motors with two HEX socket M3x25 screws (M-F3) trough the mount. Do not tighten screws fully.
Take the SFP spring mount part (M-P3).
Insert two M3 square nuts (M-F11) and one M4 nut (M-F12) into the provided slots. It needs to fit the whole way in the spring mount. Insert two TORX M3x10 (M-F6) screws.
Add washer M4 (M-F15) then, spring (M-O4) and one more washer on the screw of the SFP mount.
Screw the mount part.
Prepare Philips media converter (M-O13) and four brackets (M-P16).
Remove four screws from the Philips media converter.
Attach brackets (M-P16) to the SFP module with the TORX M3x10 screws (M-F6).
Take the media converter mount (M-P12).
Insert two M3 square nuts (M-F11) into the provided holes.
Insert, but not tighten two TORX M3x10 screws (M-F6).

brick.name: Motor Mount
brick.abstract: Mechanical module, used for mounting motors, responsible for moving the IR laser beam.
brick.long_description: The motor mount module is based around a 3D printed motor mount part, which hosts two motors controlling pointing direction of the beam, by turning two micrometer screws. Due to micro-stepping very precise alignment of units is possible. Pointing direction can change for as little as 0.6 mRad in one step.

step.description: Prepare the 3D printed motor mount (M-P13).
Insert four M4 square nuts (M-F12) and one M3 nut into the slots on the bottom part of the motor mount.
Insert one TORX M3x10 screw (M-F6). Insert two HEX socket M4x12 screws (M-F7).
Repeate on the other side.
Tighten the second screw on each side.
Attach the half-bracket (M-P17) with the TORX M3x10 (M-F6) screw. Do not tighten fully!
Insert six M4 square nuts (M-F12) into the provided slots.
Insert two HEX socket M4x12 screws (M-F7) into provided holes.
Prepare two motors (E-10), two custom M5x65 screws (M-F10), two M5 couplers (M-O8) and two long M5 nuts (M-F13).
Put nut on the screw such that it is flushed with the screw tip.
Insert the M5 coupler onto the screw.
Insert the whole assembly into the motor.
Put M5 screw trough the hole in motor mount in such a way that the hole on the nut points into the direction of previously inserted M4x10 set screw.
Repeat for the other motor.
Tighten both M4x10 set screws.
Take two HEX socket M4x45 screws (M-F5). Insert screws into provided holes trough the motor. Tighten screws all the way to the motor mounting tab. Repeat for the other motor.
Attach the universal unipolar stepper driver PCB board (E-5) with two TORX M3x10 screws (M-F6).
Prepare the 3D printed lid (M-P15).
Take the previously assembled control elecreonics.
Place it into the lid, so that the Power module PCB is facing the holes.
Fasten the electronics in place with two M3x10 TORX screws (M-F6).
Insert the waterproof eth + power cable (E-12) into the first provided hole.
Insert the power plug into the PCB board.
Insert the waterproof eth cable (E-11) into the second provided hole.

brick.name: Outdoor Enclosure
brick.abstract: Outdoor enclosure of the KORUZA system.
brick.long_description: Enclosure provides protection to the inner system and allows for mounting the system on the wall, rod or any fixed, stable object. Its design also allows the user to adjust initial pointing direction, using the green laser as a reference.

step.description: Take the square profile (M-E1).
We assemble the square profile to the U-profile (M-E2) using two HEX socket M4x12 screws (M-F7) and M4 nuts (M-F12).
Pull the screw trough both holes, such that the head is located inside the square profile. Put on the M4 nut.
Repeat on the other side.
Take the eye-bolt screw (M-F17), the L-profile (M-E3), two M10 nuts (M-F16) and a spring washer (M-F21).
Put a nut and a spring washer on the screw, then insert it into the hole located in the bottom corner of the L-profile.
Put on another nut (M-F16).
Prepare the antenna holder set (M-E4), containing the mounting piece, small U-profile, three shorter M8 screws, nuts and washers, two longer M10 screws and nuts and six M8 washers.
Prepare the largere mounting piece. Insert two M10 screws troug the hole on each side, such that heads are located on the flat side of the mounting piece.
Slide the small U-prifile on M10 nuts, such that the flat side is pointing away from the mounting piece.
Insert an M10 washer and nut on each screw.
Place the antenna holder to the side of the L-profile. Take three M8 screws from the package and pul them through the holder and the middle opening on the side of the L-profile.
Put M8 washer and nut on each screw. Fast nuts in desirable position for mounting.

Take the M10x75 screw (M-F18) and pull it through the hole located on the bottom of the square profile. Keep in mind that the screw head should be located on the inside of the square tube. Put the spring washer (M-F21) and two nuts (M-F16) on it.
Tighten the first nut such that washer sits tight in place. The function of the other nut is to secure position in the oval opening of the L-profile. Put a washer (M-F20) on it.
Take the square profile and place the L-profile on top, so that the M10x75 screw fits trough the second oval opening of the L-profile.
Prepare the M10x160 screw (M-F19) and pull it through the side-left hole on the L-profile.
Put on the spring washer (M-F21), two nuts (M-F16) and another M10 washer (M-F20).
M10x160 must fit trough the side opening of the U-Profile. Put on two more M10 (M-F16) nuts before pulling it trough the ring-bolt.
Insert another two M10 nuts (M-F16) to make the assembly symmetrical. Pull the screw all the way trough the U-profile.
Insert the washer (M-F20) and M10 nut (M-F16).
Center the square profile and L-profile and fasten all the nuts, beginning with the one closest to the L-profile.
Lastly, add a nut on the M10x75 screw to fix the L-profile in place.
The outdoor enclosure is now complete. Keep in mind, that usually you want to assamble the enclosure for another unit in the miror-like fashion to enable easier mounting.
P
